Actico Interface - Project Documentation - Main Page

    Actico Interface is a project internal to Excelian. Its aim is to connect Avaloq to Actico using a RESTful interface. The documentation provides high level information on the different parts of the project but also gives an insight on the structure of the methods and classes of the packages.

    A short description of the actual state of the project as well as the description of the packages are given below. The details of the packages is given in the section below, Packages.

Packages 
Package Description
ACTICO
Deal with the connection with ACTICO Servers, sending and receiving information.
Model
Repository of the objects of the project.

Project Description

    ACTICO is leader into automation of decision making processes and has an expertise on DMN and Business Rules and a partner of Avaloq. Being an alternative to Avaloq Business Rule Engine (BRE) Adapter built-in Avaloq Core Platform, Actico is able to run as a complement to Avaloq Core Platform to model and execute the business rules models. Previous projects have implemented a solution with both Actico and ACP either using SOAP Adapter or Avaloq BRE.
    In this project, both system are connected using RESTful interface.

    Avaloq Message Interface (AMI) connects Avaloq Core Platform and third party system – here Actico. AMI is a passive interface, i.e., it is able to create an XML file but cannot send or collect it from a server.

    Actico's software is composed of modules and we will go through three of them:
    (1) Actico Modeler, (2) Actico Team Server and (3) Actico Execution Server.

    1. Actico Modeler allows the design of decision making via a graphical interface. It belongs to Design Time. On production, business users are allowed to create, amend and delete business rules. You can see on "http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=prQJGCpLZH8" the main functionalities of Actico Modeler.
    2. Actico Team Server is a repository on the server for design time. It deals with versioning, checking in and out. This module is of main use for Raiffeisen Project.
    3. Actico Execution Server is a web application that provides the ability to execute business rules, allows exchanging and deploying Business Rules rules at runtime. Note that Actico Execution Server offers HTTP endpoints that can be used to pick the business rules model.

    In this project the connection will take place at Actico Execution Server : on the server the Business Rules models are accessed and are represented by their inputs and outputs.
    Through .wadl representation, the models are called from an external system, i.e. ACP here. The external system picks the appropriate repository and populates the input fields.
    Note that Actico Execution Server is a passive repository and doesn’t handle the sending of messages out of the server. It allows SOAP and REST calls from external system using the XML or JSON formats.
    Besides, Actico endpoints are defined and can be accessed or populated via HTTP methods – i.e., POST, GET, DELETE – using software such as Postman or SoapUI.

    The Execution Server runs the model with the inputs given by the external system, i.e. Avaloq Core Platform.

    Actico can implement a Java Messaging Service (JMS) which is dealing with the transmission of the message. It would be an additional JAVA project which would send this call. At this point, JMS is not part of the project yet.


Packages Description

    Package represents pillars of the project, they separate the different parts of the project in order to ease the readability and reusability of the productCategory.

  • Model

    Repository of the objects of the project.

    Avoid repeating the same work multiple times within the project. Encapsulate the objects in use in the classes ActicoInterface and JSONFeature. Allow hierarchical structure in the objects.
    Define the level of security regarding the access and and override of the object attributes.

    Note: Follow OOP concept.

  • ACTICO

    Deal with the connection with ACTICO Servers, sending and receiving information.

    Actico Execution Server is a runtime repository with a collection of business rules/DMN. Using .wadl file, the business rules are triggered with a specific input (of type message) and send back an output - the input and output follow the specifications of .wadl file. The input comes in the shape of a XML file or a JSON file, the execution server sends back with the same media type (e.g. XML or JSON).

    The set of methods embedded in {@link ACTICO.ActicoInterface#main ActicoInterface#main} triggers Actico Execution Server. It mimics the action of Postman (or SoapUI) when calling the Execution Server with (1) a request body containing the message and (2) a header with the media type (e.g. application/XML or application/JSON) and the authentication.

Actual state of the project

    The project is still ongoing. In order to smooth the transition of knowledge from one team to another, the issues encountered during the two months of the projects have been referenced following Kanban method. There you can see the definition of the concepts, ways to troubleshoot the issues (if any), etc.

    YouTrack from JetBrain displays the issues. You can access the issues from this link (https://actico.myjetbrains.com/youtrack/) as a guest user. Note that I use this tool to reference the issues and not to control the advancement of the project. Therefore, I didn't use the Priority and State features.

Sources

    The project is based on material from SafariBooks (O'Reilly).

  • Master Java Web Services and REST API with Spring Boot

    Master Java Web Services and REST API with Spring Boot gives an insight on how to build a RESTful interface.
    The package com.actico.restInterface is based on chapter 6 of this online course.

  • Instant Apache ActiveMQ Messaging Application Development How-to

    Instant Apache ActiveMQ Messaging Application Development How-to shows real example on how to use ActiveMQ with queues, message producer, message consumer.
    The package JMS is based on this online book. Refer to GitHub.
